body: CC: @graceguo-supercat
LGTM, for context I think `backendSync` may not be necessary anymore. Something to dig into.

+1 for elasticsearch connectivity 
would you also consider sparql endpoints ?
+1 for sparql endpoints support, it will have a great impact on linked statistical data usability.

You can use a workaround:
Just define an aggregate that would yield the original value if only one element per group is present, like, e.g. sum, min, max, avg.
Then, make sure you configure your chart to use the original time granularity.

However, this workaround is only valid, as long as the timestamps are all distinct. Otherwise the grouping would actually aggregate more than one value...

Rebased to fix conflict. @agrawaldevesh thanks for offering to help verify this PR! Regarding the timezone issue, I think it's something that runs slightly deeper in the code, so would probably require some additional planning (perhaps a SIP). Perhaps something along the lines of a setting in `superset_config.py` to specify a timezone in which all timestamps with timezone info would be cast to (naive timestamps would probably be kept unchanged)? Anyway, a really good idea worth investigating (committer guidance would be helpful).

Good workaround.

I still would like to see this as a feature. I.e. aggregations should be optional, since they may be done during the query.

Unfortunately, the team decided to push all changes into lyftga to alleviate any pain points that could occur from cherry picking changes from master into lyftga and then merging lyftga back into master. The good news is that we should be merging lyftga into master in a week and a half. So this will be in master soon!

You might want to check a tutorial on basic SQL syntax. I think what you want to do can be achieved with the following expression:
```sql
SUM(CASE WHEN "H-kode" IN ('H02', 'H05', 'H08') THEN "MÃ¦ngde i ton" ELSE NULL END) / SUM(CASE WHEN "H-kode" = 'H11' then "MÃ¦ngde i ton" ELSE NULL END)
```
while at the same time grouping by `Kommune`. This should give you just three rows of data. Oh, and that might give an error if H11 is missing or zero, so you might want to check for that, too. Hope this helps, Ville.

One general constraint for optimization that we have around this, is that we typically want to put the function/expression on the constant side of the operation, so that we can leverage partition pruning or indexes on fields.

Meaning `dttm >= 294728378` is better than `epoch_to_datetime(dttm) >= DATE('1979-07-19')`.

Database optimizers cannot leverage indexes/partitions on column altered by functions.
One more thing, I'm surprised that in your example above, Superset isn't using `STR_TO_DATE` around the time constant. Is the column's `is temporal` checkbox checked?
